title: How to make AI that users love

data.content: User-facing artificial intelligence (AI) can delight users, but it can also infuriate users in unexpected ways. The key for creators of AI (data scientists, engineers, product managers, and designers) is to not fail to meet the user’s expectation that AI has all-knowing superhuman abilities. Some common tactics are: 1. Don’t be wrong, 2. Let the user help, 3. Keep it simple, 4. Help the user understand, 5. Avoid encouraging detrimental behavior, and lastly 6. Give users a reason to care.
https://miro.medium.com/max/1256/1*fiLgPDgYzrAhMYLj9s76Zw.png

AI and machine learning are amazing technologies that can be an integral part of products that users love when designed thoughtfully. You can probably easily recall a few times when AI delighted you, and just as easily, when it frustrated you. I hope these tips can guide you — whether you’re a data scientist, engineer, designer, or product manager — on how to create delightful AI-centric products and features.

A bit about me — over the past several years, I have been creating user-facing AI and had my fair share of success and f̶a̶i̶l̶u̶r̶e̶s̶ “learnings”. My responsibilities have been primarily data science, but also include aspects of software engineering, product management, and design. At MOCAP Analytics, we created infographics for NFL and NBA fans and teams from player-tracking spatiotemporal data. At Tonal, we develop a virtual personal trainer that, among other features, counts reps, spots weight when a user struggles, tracks progress, and adjusts the weight as a user strengthens over time.

At the heart of the following guidelines is understanding the difference between the user’s perception of AI and the reality of AI. To your users and the general public, AI is perceived to be some infallible all-knowing superhuman being that knows them better than they know themselves (e.g., Jared and Fiona on Silicon Valley, baseline test in Blade Runner).

Of course, the reality is AI today is usually only passably good at the one narrow task it is trained to solve, and if anything deviates, it deteriorates quickly (a few fun examples are hacking Tesla with tape on a sign, Google Assistant fails, Google Maps directing cars into mud, fooling object recognition in images). Further, the ways AI gets tripped up are not the same as the ways humans do. The truth is that AI’s biggest advantage over human intelligence (with exceptions like AlphaGo) is not that it’s smarter than humans, but that it’s faster and cheaper. AI can classify a million images as containing a cat or a dog in an hour and for a few dollars. But ask that same AI to also classify a rabbit and you’re out of luck. Meanwhile, a human, at one image per second, would take 11 sleepless days and nights and thousands of dollars to achieve the same feat, but the rabbit’s no big deal.

An AI that doesn’t meet a user’s expectation can cause a loss of trust (see negativity bias), disengagement, demotivation, and even unintended harmful behavior. The solution is, of course, to not violate the user’s expectation, and the rest of this article explains a few strategies to further this end.
(Many examples come from Google because they are well known and because Google is advancing both AI technology and AI user experience. I have no affiliation.)
1 — Don’t Be Wrong

While AI can be very accurate, no AI is 100% accurate. You might be thinking that if AI can’t always be right, then how can I possibly follow “Don’t Be Wrong”? There are ways to avoid or mitigate situations that have a strict correct vs. incorrect dichotomy.
https://miro.medium.com/max/5172/1*qJSv5iH7t9ylPKgv252pKg.png
https://miro.medium.com/max/5632/1*yd0CVpDmWDSVxLJSBoA6ug.png
2 — Let the User Help
Sometimes a little help from your friend, the user, can go a long way in enabling AI to do more while also acting as the user expects.
https://miro.medium.com/max/1508/1*LGr4opRR8a4908Lue5tKCw.png
https://miro.medium.com/max/1588/1*9CgnhL10ffXt5KOHm-DFvg.png
3 — Keep It Simple
Users rarely spend more than a few seconds thinking about something before they decide it’s too complicated.
https://miro.medium.com/max/1956/0*aZkEyyXIaqs5xzdF
4 — Help the User Understand

When interacting with people, we naturally follow up statements with our reasons. “You should use the Brave internet browser instead of Google Chrome” rings hollow, even impersonal and demanding, without adding, “because you care about data privacy.” However, AI is often not designed to do the same. While it can be challenging to explain the inner workings of a neural network, there are ways to help the user understand AI’s reasoning.
https://miro.medium.com/max/4328/1*-XpOwCoevFSNOIc1roxDuQ.png
5 — Avoid Encouraging Detrimental Behavior

Users will do what is needed to get the result they want from your AI, whether that’s a higher score, credit for their actions, or anything else. Via your AI, there is a value system imposed on them. Sometimes users’ actions may not be what you intended, and could be harmful and counter to the initial purpose (Goodhart’s Law).

A positive example is Google’s fitness tracking, which has, as its primary metric, a simple calculation based on minutes a user was active that encourages all types of activity and places extra emphasis on any intense activity, thereby imposing few unnecessary values on users.
https://miro.medium.com/max/3432/1*xOl7uMOynAXc9LzuyISaXQ.png

A negative example is fitness trackers that focus primarily on steps and calorie burn. Steps are the most common form of activity, nearly everyone walks or runs, but almost no one exclusively walks or runs as their only form of exercise. Users complain that they don’t get credit for strength training, cycling, swimming, etc. Some users may even be less likely to do those exercises because they do not get credit in this implied system of values.

Another negative example is peer reviews gone too far. An executive once excitedly told me of an elaborate AI (Markov chain) system of questions and scoring to determine employees’ promotions and compensation. It’s not hard to imagine the employees, first, demanding to know the inner workings of this system given its power over them, and second, acting to optimize how they are perceived in this value system, even at the expense of the company’s broader success. Stock shares or options might have been the better choice.
6 — Give Users a Reason to Care

When it comes to insights, metrics, charts, and other data-centric results, “useful” is better than “cool”. Useful results provoke action or a change in attitude that impacts the future. In contrast, a cool result might capture attention at first, but it doesn’t lead anywhere and is mostly entertainment — eye candy or a factoid to bring up in idle conversation. Surface what matters and provide details and charts to back it up. Your users should have positive answers to a few of these questions after seeing your AI’s data-centric result:

In addition, letting users self explore more detailed rawer data is a way to help them understand, as explained earlier. The transparency reinforces their trust in the main message or story and the underlying AI and product, even if they rarely look at the detailed data.

An example is Android’s data usage tracking. It shows a chart of the mobile data usage over the monthly billing cycle and a list of apps sorted by data usage. It provides obvious answers to the user’s burning questions.
https://miro.medium.com/max/2546/1*3ThQ3n7PUZgZDJOO91RcxA.png
Further, users can select previous months and other options to explore and get more context, e.g., looking for patterns like usage spikes on weekends.
It’s also worth noting what this screen does not do.
Conclusion

Creating successful AI products is challenging. Hopefully some of these guidelines will be useful, but they can contradict each other sometimes. Ultimately, success requires thoughtfulness, early feedback from users, and close collaboration between data scientists, software engineers, product managers, and designers.
